In practice the range at which a whistle may be heard is extremely variable and depends critically on weather conditions; the values given can be regarded as typical but under conditions of strong wind or high ambient noise level at the listening post the range may be much reduced. (L.N. 53 of 2016)

section.name: sd
section.heading: Directional properties
section.content: The sound pressure level of a directional whistle shall be not more than 4 dB below the prescribed sound pressure level on the axis at any direction in the horizontal plane within ±45° of the axis. The sound pressure level at any other direction in the horizontal plane shall be not more than 10 dB below the prescribed sound pressure level on the axis, so that the range in any direction will be at least half the range on the forward axis. The sound pressure level shall be measured in that 1/3rd-octave band which determines the audibility range.

section.name: se
section.heading: Positioning of whistles
section.content: When a directional whistle is to be used as the only whistle on a vessel, it shall be installed with its maximum intensity directed straight ahead.

A whistle shall be placed as high as practicable on a vessel, in order to reduce interception of the emitted sound by obstructions and also to minimize hearing damage risk to personnel. The sound pressure level of the vessel’s own signal at listening posts shall not exceed 110 dB(A) and so far as practicable should not exceed 100 dB(A).

section.name: sf
section.heading: Fitting of more than one whistle
section.content: If whistles are fitted at a distance apart of more than 100 m, it shall be so arranged that they are not sounded simultaneously.

section.name: sg
section.heading: Combined whistle systems
section.content: If due to the pressure of obstructions the sound field of a single whistle or of one of the whistles referred to in subparagraph (f) is likely to have a zone of greatly reduced signal level, it is recommended that a combined whistle system be fitted so as to overcome this reduction. For the purposes of the Rules a combined whistle system is to be regarded as a single whistle. The whistles of a combined system shall be located at a distance apart of not more than 100 m and arranged to be sounded simultaneously. The frequency of any one whistle shall differ from those of the others by at least 10 Hz.

section.name: sa
section.heading: Intensity of signal
section.content: A bell or gong, or other device having similar sound characteristics shall produce a sound pressure level of not less than 110 dB at a distance of 1 m from it.

section.name: sb
section.heading: Construction
section.content: Bells and gongs shall be made of corrosion-resistant material and designed to give a clear tone. The diameter of the mouth of the bell shall be not less than 300 mm for vessels of 20 metres or more in length. Where practicable, a power-driven bell striker is recommended to ensure constant force but manual operation shall be possible. The mass of the striker shall be not less than 3 percent of the mass of the bell. (L.N. 53 of 2016)

section.name: s3
section.heading: Approval
section.content: The construction of sound signal appliances, their performance and their installation on board the vessel shall be to the satisfaction of the appropriate authority of the State whose flag the vessel is entitled to fly.

section.name: s1
section.leadIn: The following signals, used or exhibited either together or separately, indicate distress and need of assistance:

subsection.name: a
subsection.content:
a gun or other explosive
signals fired at intervals of about a minute; (L.N. 53 of 2016)

subsection.name: b
subsection.content: a continuous sounding with any fog-signalling apparatus;

subsection.name: c
subsection.content: rockets or shells, throwing red stars fired one at a time at short intervals;

subsection.name: d
subsection.content: a signal made by any signalling method consisting of the group ··· — — — ··· (SOS) in the Morse Code; (L.N. 53 of 2016)

subsection.name: e
f
subsection.content: the International Code Signal of distress indicated by N.C.;

subsection.name: g
subsection.content: a signal consisting of a square flag having above or below it a ball or anything resembling a ball;

subsection.name: h
subsection.content: flames on the vessel (as from a burning tar barrel, oil barrel, etc.);

subsection.name: i
subsection.content: a rocket parachute flare or a hand-flare showing a red light; (L.N. 53 of 2016)

subsection.name: j
subsection.content: a smoke signal giving off orange-coloured smoke;

subsection.name: k
subsection.content: slowly and repeatedly raising and lowering arms outstretched to each side;

subsection.name: l
subsection.leadIn: a distress alert by means of digital selective calling (DSC) transmitted on:

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: VHF channel 70, or

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: MF/HF on the frequencies 2187.5 kHz, 8414.5 kHz, 4207.5 kHz, 6312 kHz, 12577 kHz or 16804.5 kHz; (L.N. 53 of 2016)

subsection.name: m
subsection.content: a ship-to-shore distress alert transmitted by the ship’s Inmarsat or other mobile satellite service provider ship earth station; (L.N. 53 of 2016)

subsection.name: n
subsection.content: signals transmitted by emergency position-indicating radio beacons;

subsection.name: o
subsection.content: approved signals transmitted by radiocommunications systems, including survival craft radar transponders. (L.N. 365 of 1989; L.N. 486 of 1995; 36 of 2000 s. 28)

section.name: s2
section.content: The use or exhibition of any of the foregoing signals, except for the purpose of indicating distress and need of assistance and the use of other signals which may be confused with any of the above signals, is prohibited.

section.name: s3
section.leadIn: Attention is drawn to the relevant sections of the International Code of Signals, the International Aeronautical and Maritime Search and Rescue Manual, Volume III and the following signals: (L.N. 53 of 2016)

subsection.name: a
subsection.content: a piece of orange-coloured canvas with either a black square and circle or other appropriate symbol (for identification from the air);

subsection.name: b
subsection.content: a dye marker.
